title: How many public Level 2 and DC Fast electric vehicle charging stations will be available in the US as of 29 April 2022?
preds: There are 47,097 as of 27th April so this is barely a prediction. Wish I'd seen this one earlier!

I say it is fewer than 49,000 because of the data that was shown on the website. It says that right now in America there is about 47,000 and the deadline for thsi data is in 4 days. So in my mind, I don't see how they can make about 2,000 in 4 days.

Updating the original forecast. This reflects my original estimate, but I had put in buffers for the "never say never". Removing the buffers now that we're close to the end of the question time frame.
Needs to see a 121 stations/day rate until resolution. That is a higher rate for a longer period of time than the biggest negative rate seen during the duration of this question.
as of 5 april - since last forecase (22Mar) - increase was 362 or an average of 25 per day (362/14) = extrapolating that out - 25pd x 17 days until question close is still shy of 47000 (46825)
Darn, haven't updated this for a long time...
as of Mar 22 - still barely over 46000 (46023)...Unless there is a massive influx, i don't see 3000 stations coming online in the next 35 days

The recent, large swings downward has made me weary that there might be similar large swings to the upside that is possible. I am therefore revising my forecast back to include some chance of >49k stations.

I went back and looked at all the conversations and the variety of good base rate data. I previously made an assumption that the money used for the EVs would have to come from the government. With private investment, you could buy over 49K BUT it is not clear yet, that there is enough private investment. As a team, we have varying numbers of total number of chargers. As of today via https://afdc.energy.gov/stations/#/analyze?country=US&fuel=ELEC there are 45,842 total. @JasonSmith has a total of 5000 and @ricknsusan1314 using this link https://www.energy.gov/eere/vehicles/articles/fotw-1089-july-8-2019-there-are-more-68800-electric-vehicle-charging-units shows 68,880. Think needs to be an agreement on how many there are today and how many have been added over last couple of years. According to https://afdc.energy.gov/data/10964 " In 2021 alone, the number of charging stations grew by over 55%." Even if it doubled again for 2022, if we believe the 1st number, that gives us approximately 92K, then the US would have to setting up 7666K per month and that is not happening. Therefore I have upped my previous percentage for fewer than 49K and down-checked everything else accordingly.
A puzzling reduction of about 400 stations. Will those numbers come back in a future update?

Overcorrection a few weeks ago. Based on the current 3-4 month opening average, there is going to actually be a ~1k shortage. I struggled to think of possible accelerants that could shift stations past the 49k mark (build back better?). Also concerned how the crisis in Ukraine could impact federal investment domestically, but this is likely a longer-term prospect out-of-scope of the forecast.
with last week's negative rate i cannot see any chance >0.1% so I will take the dive and do something I not often do - set my best guess to 100%
March 1 numbers showed a shade over 46000 - there is an increase in ports but not the station data isn't reflective - so more ports at stations that already exist. more than 49k is a hardsell
Revising forecast based on not having seen any movement on distribution of this $5B in funding to states.

Seen enough. All in. The projected gap between the last months’ accumulation rates and what it would take to exceed 49k at this point, combined with a pretty short time horizon make me assess the chances of a bin #2+ outcome at < 0.5%.
47,012 stations as of 2/22/22.  Anything over 49,000 would require 1,000/month...a rate never achieved yet.
Signal growing weaker, and time getting closer.  It is not likely construction timelines will rapidly catch up in time for a change.
They've added only 620 in a little over a month, looks very unlikely.
Redoing, made a mistake in point allocation per bucket.
February is on track to be a good month, despite previous performances (concerning February). The margins are still really close if you look strictly at the numbers.
46,885 today, an anomalous 30/day over the past two days. Reminder: we need 27/day to hit 49,000.

Amending forecast based based on extended time required for states to submit plans and win approval.  The highest growth of stations in the past 5 years occurred between 2019-2020. During that year 21,735 stations were built, which is equal to ~1,811 stations per month. https://afdc.energy.gov/fuels/electricity_infrastructure_trends.html Given that the Biden administration only unveiled the of $5B in funding for EV stations over the next 5 years on Thursday, Feb 9th I surmise that in optimal circumstances it would be 30 days at very best case before a state could submit its plans, win federal approval, and put the stations on contract. If all of that happened prior to March, and then the production of said stations occurred at the best case rate detailed above, that would add 3,622 stations prior to April 29th.  This would bring the total number of stations to ~ 49,9089. Again, this is based on the most optimal of circumstances occurring.
Updating for passage of time, with no significant change in the rate of accumulation of new stations in the meantime.
Not actually updating, just noting. 46825 today.
Adjusting further toward the lower end as the deadline is getting closer and the goal is still somewhat far off.
@TDHesslink your math makes sense to me given the timeline, changing accordingly.

https://www.msn.com/en-us/money/companies/us-to-detail-dollar5-billion-plan-to-fund-ev-charging-network/ar-AATGuBy?ocid=BingNewsSearch "The administration will make $615 million available in 2022 but states must first submit plans and win federal approval" Maybe this question will be asked again with a November resolution date. At no time in the past have I seen 1,000 stations built in a month which is close to what would have to happen to reach into the second bin of this resolution.
Nice to see a ‘28-day’ to put the record right on track. Can we get another ?

Based on historical trends, you would expect about 1,000-1,500 new charging stations to be built over the next three months. There are currently less than 47,000, so if construction continued at its standard pace there would be less than 49,000 by April 29th. Although several EV companies do have plans to dramatically expand the charging station infrastructure in the U.S. this year, funding from the Bipartisan Infrastructure Bill has still not yet been distributed, so the timeline for these plans will most likely be further down the line and not impact this forecast.

Will need a daily average of >28 stations installed per day over next 11 weeks. This is 75% higher than the current daily average over a three week term.
Will adjust forecast and reassess if there is a significant increase, or a large project installation completed.
The website is trending positively.  Plus, I believe my previous forecasts were overstated and too optimistic. https://afdc.energy.gov/stations/#/analyze?country=US&fuel=ELEC
I did my math wrong in a big way the first time around.

I just did a proper forecast, taking a normal distribution of the daily rate variation i have seen so far and forecasted 100 scenarios. It looks pretty much unrealistic to get >49k. I am, based on previous experience, going to disregard the crowd here and trust my own analysis.

The technology is still evolving, the pricing structure varies from provider to provider and some of the installation models require the business that installs the chargers to pay for the electricity (which might be offset by use) as well as the O&M of the equipment...not a lot of incentive to install chargers.
January finished stronger than average. Looking at that average since last April, the forecast is almost right on the 49000 mark. Historically, February always seems to be below Jan so we shall see!

With govt funding support and significant push by major auto makers into the EV market expected this year, interests are aligned among major constituents including states, car companies, infrastructure players and private capital.

Build-out added 4 units over the weekend. Forecasting the possibility of a small number of bigger installation initiatives reaching completion, but also a much greater number of ‘0’ days. New vehicle sales (US)  for Dec ‘21 are 12.8 million; statistically at very low end of 20 year range. https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/TOTALSA December auto inventories report seems to be delayed, 
( https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/AUINSA ) but also likely to be very low, limiting the increase in demand for new charging ports.
Public funding for the initiatives may also be a limiting factor on this build-out.
46,583 today. 15/day since the beginning of the month. So, indeed, the daily rate is picking up a bit.

Halftime forecast:
1707 (net) stations have been added in the 3 months since this question opened (92 days, for those who enjoy being more precise in these things). 3 months to go. To be simplistic: 1,707 + 46,583 currently reported = 48,290 << 49k
Fans of precision will note that since Feb. has fewer days, there are actually only 90 days left to exceed 49k / avoid bin#1.  If average rates apply in the coming months, we can expect to see:
Mar. 1: ~47,130 stations reported 
Apr. 1: ~ 47,700 stations reported At this point I’m quite puzzled as to why so many people still forecast bin #2 as their most likely outcome…?!

As the daily rate is low now even long after the holidays I will shift this a bit towards the lowermost bin. One way to look at the current situation: To get to 49k now, we would need to average more than 27 stations added per day until April. This did actually happen the 4 weeks leading up to Xmas but is untrue apart from that since my counting began beginning of November. So it would need to stay at the December level all the way the next 3 months. That looks increasingly unrealistic.
46,527 today, for 30+ / day over the past two days. Holding steady here.

Adjusting to align with reduced rate of installations. 
Will monitor for increase rate as weather improves to possibly increase construction.

46,525 as of Jan 23. Roughly 19.15/day were added over the last 3 months. With 96 days to go that would put it at +1838, or a disappointing 48,363. To get past 53k the rate would have to triple, which doesn't seem likely. Although there are likely more to be added once winter passes the pace still needs more than a 30% increase to even pass bin 1, and with Build Back Better in irons even that looks like a stretch. Should've updated sooner as this one now looks like it's going to fall short.

Great sharing here as well as the math (it does appear sound).  I have adjusted my outcome accordingly.  The doubt I still have is the effect of Biden's intended policy...does anyone have anything new (like the past few weeks) on the administration's plan/likelihood to implement in earnest?  I can only find mid-Dec news plus background...

Currently, DC has 5,655 Level 2 EV charging stations and 1,203 DC fast EV charging stations. The influx of money to build more charging stations will not be available until next fiscal year. Also, the stations need to be planned and built. Updating to remove absolutes.
Re-read question specifics and adjusted accordingly.

Changing my forecast based on this DOE chart visualizing an even steeper upward trend in the number of stations.  This chart shows the growth of U.S. public and private electric vehicle (EV) charging infrastructure since 2011. The number of electric vehicle supply equipment (EVSE) ports has grown consistently, and the number of EV charging station locations has also increased steadily. The National Renewable Energy Laboratory started tracking the two figures separately in 2014. Between 2015 and 2019, the number of charging stations nearly doubled. In 2020 alone, the number of charging stations grew by 18% (https://afdc.energy.gov/data/10964).
Updating back up - in previous years, charger construction (or at least registration) has picked up throughout Q1 relative to January figures.
The pace has been slow and there probably won't be any more sudden jumps. Switching to favor bin 1.

Would love to see the trimmed down BBB legislation as well as data on government subsidies on EVs…also missing is time horizon on domestic automakers to produce a majority of EVs.  Anyone have some or all from good source? Also missing is election probability and partisan stances on BBB EV initiatives. Lastly, Tesla financial data on network expansion will fill a void.
Now at 46,302, up 140 in 12 days for that consistent low average. Note to self to check to see whether early January figures are typically indicative of trends through the next few months.

I have downloaded results in CSV from https://afdc.energy.gov/stations/#/analyze?country=US&fuel=ELEC, and analyzed them using the "open date" field.
At the end of October 2021, sum of "EV Level 2 EVSE" + "EV DC Fast" = 42,615.
At the end of December 2021, sum of "EV Level 2 EVSE" + "EV DC Fast" = 46,898.
Therefore we have a growth rate of 46.5543 per day. The period 20220101-20220428 at the same rate would give us 5,493 additional stations. Based on this, the expected value for Apr 29 would be 52,391
I detect huge variations in the "open date", a significant number in Dec 21 and Oct 21 compared to Nov 21, and a huge peak in Jan 21. This may be caused by the manual work in registering new data. 
(1) On the positive side, we can expect some acceleration thanks to the federal incentives set up in order to meet a very ambitious goal for 2030 established by President Joe Biden. This was announced in Aug 21, so it may start having impact now.
(2) On the negative side, the outcome will be determined using data reported on 29 April 2022, but we have seen some delay in data reporting. As a consequence, the published number may be missing the 200-400 new stations opened in the last days of April but still not registered.
I will put more weight on factor (1) and consider an expected number of 53,000, therefore I evenly distribute the odds in bins two and three.

The past period of slower-than-usual accumulation plus net rollback of the count by more than 100 early in the New Year now suggest we will most likely get a “high bin #1” outcome. Noteworthy that there have been very few large fluctuations in the accumulation rate so far.
It is hard to get an exact number of chargers already in existence.  It appears there may be only around 5000 fast chargers, which appears to include Level 2 and DC.

Currently, DC has  5,655 Level 2 EV charging stations and 1,203 DC fast EV charging stations. The influx of money to build more charging stations will not be available until next fiscal year. Also, the stations need to be planned and built.

The popularity of electric vehicles is growing exponentially.  Based on the number of observed charging stations in the DC metro area, the demand is outpacing supply for charging stations.  When combined with upcoming laws in the Northeast US that will limit the number of gas powered vehicles being sold, it is reasonable to believe that the need for charging stations throughout the US will grow.

Changing to the lower band due to progress slowing to almost a crawl over the last 30 days. Likely due to weather impacts, but the industry capacity to significantly increase installation doesn't exist so it is unlikely a surge will make up ground.

IAW the USDOE website.  As of May 2019, there were more than 68,800 Level 2 and DC fast charging units throughout the United States. Of that total, 16%, or approximately 10,860 units, were DC fast chargers [https://www.energy.gov/eere/vehicles/articles/fotw-1089-july-8-2019-there-are-more-68800-electric-vehicle-charging-units].  As of January 11, 2022 (essentially 2021 numbers), there are 46,276 [https://afdc.energy.gov/stations/#/analyze?country=US&fuel=ELEC].  Using straight-line interpolation and assuming demand trends remain constant, 81,692 are forecast by 2023.  However, COVID and supply chain issues may dampen the current installation trend (less than 81,692).

Relied pretty heavily on the data from the fuel station locator. Also, did anyone else notice the huge spike in stations on January 2021? At any rate, looking at the data a few ways I decided to modulate my forecast on a typical winter monthly average. I assumed the previous January was victim to some coding error, and that the monthly average would range between 450-550 stations added a month, during the timeframes of January-April. I am feeling somewhat comfortable with this assessment given that we are only at 232 for the month thus far (Jan 2022).  Supply-chain issues have had a huge impact on EV production, so I can't help but wonder what the impact would be on charging equipment, especially specialized/proprietary stations.

Hill article referenced approx 42k on Oct 1; Jan 11 data called out 46276 = an increase of approx 4300 over 3.5 months; april 29 is approx 3.5 months from current date - assuming standard growth increase - that would result in 50.5k by end of april
potential for slow down on installation due to weather/covid - made me have a higher percentage on the lower end compared to exceeding the 49k-53k range

Installation of level 2 and DC Fast charging stations appear to be on the rise. President Biden has pledged 500,000 new charging stations in an undetermined amount of time. Right now I assess that time to have the money allocated before the end of his term. Money asked for in the bipartisan infrastructure law for climate change/clean energy initiatives has been difficult to hold onto. As the President asked for 15B, he only received 7.5 which I am mostly assuming is from 2022-2026. If just taking basic averages, that would equate to installing 100,000/yr. Each Level 2, 2-charger pedestal and installation would cost $5813. @ 7.5B would give you 1,290,212 pedestals. Each Level 2, DC Fast charger pedestal and installation would cost $78,020 @ 7.5B would give you 96,129 pedestals. So in either case you are unable to get to total of 500,000 pedestals without some serious subsidies or something to offset the cost. Or you have to reduce the desired amount. And all of that adds up to, it is Mid-January therefore the 7.5B has likely been allocated, but would be difficult to spend, organize and finalize the number of pedestals we're discussing. Therefore, I think there will be fewer than 49,000 built by 29 April.
At 46,286 versus 1/1's 46,162 today, for an average of 13 per day, ish.

On January 9, 2022 there are 46,286 DC Fast and Level 2 charging stations in the US (113,454 ports total; average of 2.45 ports / station).  Rates of growth from USDoE reporting:
Q-FY(MM): DC Fast growth / Level 2 growth. **Level 1 growth has remained flat or declined each quarter**
1Q20(J-M): 10.6% / 7.2%
2Q20(A-J): 6.8% / 3.1 %
3Q20(J-S): 8.4% / 6.9%
4Q20(O-D): 10.8% / 9.1 %
1Q21(J-M): 0.4% / 5.1%
2Q21(A-J): 6.9% / 4.7%
3Q21(J-S):
4Q21(O-D): Joseph R. Biden administration has established a goal of building a national public charging network of 500,000 EVSE ports by 2030. To meet
this goal by 2030, approximately 14,706 public EVSE port installations will be required each quarter for the next 9 years, requiring a significant increase from the 5,322 public EVSE ports that have been installed each quarter on average since the start of 2020.  Biden rate: 14,706 ports per quarter / 2.45 ports = 6,002 stations per quarter, or 2000 stations per month.
Current rate: 5,322 ports per quarter / 2.45 ports = 2,172 stations per quarter, or 724 stations per month. 
Assumption is that this public growth will be entirely DC Fast or Level 2 capability.  If the current rate holds, we should expect 2,896 stations to be built between January 1 and April 29, 2022, resulting in 49,182 stations. 
If the Biden rate becomes reality, we might expect 8,000 stations to be built between January 1 and April 29, 2022, resulting in 54,286 stations.  It is my opinion the true growth will be somewhere in between these numbers given legislation, COVID impact, and political will.

I am going to ignore the crowd and just go by the numbers. Based on variability in daily build-out rate, it looks near impossible to get >53 but I am putting *some* probability in the higher bins just to hedge a tiny bit for some wild scenarios unfolding.
As of right now (5 days into 2022), we're at a rate of 10 per day, so I will update ever so slightly toward that bottom bucket, and continue to do so if things don't pick up.

Public EVSE ports have been increasing by around 3.5 to 9% a quarter since the end of 2019. As of January 5, 2022, there were ~113,000 ports representing ~46,000 stations. Each station has an average of ~2.5 ports. Assuming port numbers grow at 5% over the first quarter of 2022 to ~118,000 EVSE ports, that would be around 48,000 stations. One factor mitigating this projection: President Biden pledged to add 500,000 ports by 2030 and business has responded favorably to his push, suggesting there will be an effort to achieve higher numbers than the quarterly average to date.

46,171 is the current number of locations with 68 planned.  However, looking at the downloaded data, I found the following data on opening stations.  I used a rough estimate of 1000 stations a month. (of note--Jan 21 was 10x higher than anything else, I don't have a reason, but I am calling that an outlier.   So starting at 46K + 4 months.  
2021/Jan. 11031
Feb 639
Mar 598
Apr 876
May 845
Jun 704
Jul 772
Aug 833
Sep 1469
Oct 1945
Nov 856
Dec 1119

I went for a walk and decided that I was doing a principled thing in an unprincipled way, so I'll just model my uncertainties straight out via Monte Carlo. Here they are: A) I'm not sure if the rate of new charger construction will proceed apace or increase. I think it's pretty likely it'll increase a bit, and pretty unlikely it'll decrease.
B) I'm not sure if new "construction" will "spike" in any month between now and April
C) If "construction" spikes, I'm not sure how much it will spike. And some distributions here
A) It looks like over the last three or so years, we've had a mostly linear trend of an additional 30 new chargers per month, which ain't nothing. I think in general things are likely to accelerate, and it looks like the SD is about 10, so I'll model this as Normal(40,10)
B) I count three "spikes" over the course of the last 48 months, for a base rate of 6.25%.
C) In two cases, spikes seem to be in about the amount of the last year's annual figure, and in one case it's double that figure. I think double is just really unlikely (adding 42,000 chargers in one go?) so I'll ignore that, but this starts to look weird if I assume that there's a 6.25% chance of a one-go increase of 20,000 chargers.  I'll keep the baseline monthly level to about 1000. Here's my code: a <- rnorm(10000, 30, 10)
b <- rpois(10000, 1000+a)
c <- b + (rbinom(10000,1,0.0625) * rexp(10000,1/10000))
d <- 46162 + c*4 Honestly, this gives a crazy amount of mass on 49-53k. So I'm just going to even it out a bit.
Editing mostly as a reminder to myself to indicate that I'll update these figures biweekly to accord with progress made from 46,161 from New Year's on.

April 29 is 118 days away. In 2021, the US evidently built Level 2 and DC Fast charging stations at the rate of 57.8 per day, up from 21 per day in 2020 and 10 per day in 2019. So let's stake out a few markers here: - If construction proceeds at the same rate as in 2021, we're looking at 6800 new chargers, which puts us right at the 53,000 line.
- If construction rates double, as they've roughly been doing, we're looking at 13,600 new chargers, which puts us at the 60,000 line.
- If construction rates MORE than double, as they've been doing a bit more precisely for the past two years, then we're in 61k+ territory. So all in all, at least initially, I'm not disposed to put much credence in either of the lowest two buckets. But thanks to @Ryan-Beck, we know that spikes in the historical data indicate re-categorizations of existing chargers, not necessarily actual installations, so perhaps I mean "construction" not construction. Our 2021 rate looks a lot more like our 2020 rate if we take the January 2021 chargers out of the equation. If chargers open at that rate, then we're at just about 49,000, so perhaps I should give that some more credence. Here's some more information - the dataset is up-to-date for today, the first day of the year, with twelve chargers evidently already in place. Hm. In December 2021, we have 1072 opening. In November we have 800. In October, ~2000! The monthly rate barely dropped below 600 in 2021, and didn't rise above 2000. I think that should be out 95% CI to start with. That puts us between 48500 at the low end and 54,000 at the high end. I think that's a big update for me. I'll take a step back and think of this just as a Poisson process with a mean of 1000, e.g. a slightly bumped-up mean for 2021 from February to December. When we model it like that, we have the bulk of the distribution under 53,000, so I'll take that as my main hint and plant a flag here.

~ 1/3 of the time frame for this Question has elapsed.
46,250 stations on the books today. 
122 days to go. 
+22.52 stations/day on avg. from the day that the Question opened to now.
“Status quo” reference scenario: 2748 new stations to be added (48,998 total). That does make it tricky to be confident in any one bin. I also don’t see any reason to weight any “increasing rate” or “decreasing rate” storylines preferentially compared to the “flat rate” scenario.
I really do not get the low probability people assign to <49k. The numbers are not all that encouraging with my central estimate at 49352.

With the number jump explained it's likely down to available time (Thanks @ryan-beck !).  The BBB Act could accelerate but with the unknown timeframe on that going through I'll come down as a hedge. If it happens quickly in the new year it could impact this questions resolution, if it takes a couple more months it could mean nothing
Data jumps explained - nothing to worry about.

A few of the political hurdles have been removed and the DOT std will be finished by march. Probably won't make much difference to the rate in the next few months of winter. Though winter would be a good time to do the work in the southern states. Still sticking most strongly to current rates

The month of November added approximately 500 stations to just under 46K. Build rate would have to nearly double to approximately 1000/month to break 53K. That is very unlikely. Therefore reducing all fields greater than 53K and putting probability back into the lowest bin < 49K.
Shifting heavily toward the first two bins (thanks @m_collier for the number per day)

Based on the insight provided by @Ryan-Beck (why speculate when you can just write an email and find out!) that the data jumps relate to a re-formatting / alignment of the data to a standard protocol, future large jumps in station counts now seem much less likely to me. I’m calculating an average of 22.67 new stations/day since the Question opened. 138 days to go. So, given today’s 45,896 stations, this leads to a “status quo” expectation of 49,024 stations when the Question closes. 49k is clearly a very well-chosen bin boundary! (Otherwise this would’ve been a much less interesting forecast.)

I emailed the people who ran the website to ask about the data jump early this year, below is their response. It sounds like the big jump was because two companies or data sources were added which added more stations and broke existing ones out into multiples. So it seems less likely to me that we see another sudden big jump. "As you noted, there is a jump in EV charging station counts starting in February 2021 because the National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) is transitioning EV charging counting logic to align with the hierarchy defined in the Open Charge Point Interface (OCPI; https://evroaming.org/ocpi-background/) protocol: stations, electric vehicle supply equipment (EVSE) ports, and connectors. With this transition, the number of charging outlets in the Stations Locator is being updated to represent the number of EVSE ports (or number of vehicles that can charge simultaneously) at a station location, rather than the number of connectors previously counted. The Station Locator still identifies the available connector types.  NREL imports networked EV charging data, including Blink, ChargePoint, Electrify America, EVgo, FLO, Greenlots, SemaConnect, OpConnect and Webasto, via each network’s application programming interface (API). Most networks have adopted the OCPI protocol to support roaming agreements with other networks, and to date, NREL has integrated Electrify America, EVgo, Greenlots, and ChargePoint’s OCPI-based APIs. Additionally, all non-networked charging data in the Station Locator follow the OCPI protocol.  Greenlots and ChargePoint’s OCPI APIs were integrated last in January 2021. This resulted in jumps in station counts because of the way that station data were shared under the protocol: in many cases, one station split out into several new stations to represent different physical locations of EVSE ports at one address. While the new stations shared the same street address, they have different coordinates. Additionally, jumps in station counts were attributed to new installations being added via the APIs.  For more information about the data in the Station Locator, visit the following page: https://afdc.energy.gov/stations/#/find/nearest?show_about=true."
Hedging toward the crowd a bit on the lower end, though I still think there's a good chance we'll see a large update at some point.

I don't actually understand the crowd's low prob for <49k - it seems 49k is roughly the central estimate meaning that half the probability should be in the lower bin which is miles away from the crowd at a scanty 16%. Moreover, the pulses in the data looks to be roughly 7 months apart. The last pulse was in end of october so that means the next pulse might not be until may or june 2022, so there is likely to be a low rate of build-out reported going until April. In fact, I am worried that my probability for <49k is not high enough and that I, like before, is getting too influenced by the crowd.

47K charge stations as of September 2021 with projection to grow based on details provided from team forecast.   Demand for EV/charge access will exceed current supply, but do not have a firm understanding of timeline (construction, permits, ready to provide service) to build more.   As of Sept. 21, there were approximately 122,550 charging ports at more than 47,000 public and private stations, according to the U.S. Department of Energy's Alternative Fuels Data Center. This massive increase in EV charging infrastructure will have important implications for the grid, and present stakeholders with significant challenges - and opportunities. https://www.smartgridobserver.com/EV-Summit/index.htm#:~:text=EV%20Charging%20Infrastructure%20Summit%20-%20North%20America%202022,an%20estimated%2018.7%20million%20EVs%20on%20the%20road.

My newest extrapolation from the past month’s data seems to be pointing almost exactly towards a 49k bin boundary outcome on 29 April. For reasons expressed in previous forecasts, it still seems most likely that a boost from back-logged records will push total counts into bin #2, but for now I’m adding a bit more probability to bin #1, particularly envisioning the scenario where the expected boost does not occur and where current trends continue to just barely miss 49k. Alternatively, if new stations get added even more slowly in the next months, e.g., if the economy hits a big snag, then bin #1 outcomes could be credible even if some extra back-logged records are added in the future!

Using estimated base rates from #TDHesslink and future projection/ratio calculations from #dwittmer, the range is centered on 49K (ideal) – 53K (max) potential range.  I adjust favorably with the $25 billion grants now available under the signed infrastructure bill; however, difficult to see significant acceleration given the forecast date (Apr 2022) and continued supply-chain issues nationwide reliant on materials used in chargers.

~ 1/12 of the question timeframe has now elapsed, with 330 new stations accumulating over the past 13 days (just over 25/day avg.).  Assuming ~770/mo rate continues, we’d expect ~49,440 stations by end of April. (770/mo x 5.5 months + 45,206 today).
That’s JUST over the first bin threshold. However, as @ulf and I have been pointing out in previous posts, there is a significant chance that several thousand additional records will suddenly be added to the running tally before April (historically there seem to be large pulses of new entries every so many months), so there is still a non-trivial chance of hitting bin #3 even if current day-to-day accumulation rates persist, assuming we see at least one of these pulses. Probability in all other bins reflects assessed chances of changes in the accumulation rate caused by economic / infrastructure drivers changing the outcome significantly away from that predicted by the logic above.

According to the US Department of Energy website, there are currently 45,058 EV charging stations in the United States (including Alaska, Hawaii, and US territories) (https://afdc.energy.gov/fuels/electricity_locations.html#/analyze?country=US&fuel=ELEC). The Biden administration is proposing to grow that to 500k charging stations by 2030 (https://thehill.com/opinion/technology/574926-how-the-us-can-build-ev-charging-infrastructure-that-works). Even with the new infrastructure bill, it will likely take a few years for that growth to gain momentum and the growth will be exponentially higher as we approach 2030. For now, the growth is likely to remain relatively consistent with current levels about 7.3% as in Q1 2021 over Q4 2020. (https://afdc.energy.gov/files/u/publication/electric_vehicle_charging_infrastructure_trends_first_quarter_2021.pdf). Therefore, the US is likely to have about 52k EV charging stations over the next six months by the end of April 2022.

Just checked the website again, last week's rate is about 21 new points/day which would put us at only 45k by 29th April. As I think one week of numbers is quite uncertain, I am just revising my previous forecast towards a lower estimate. I will keep tracking the changes in the numbers on the website. I am a bit skeptical about the 21/day figure as it is really low compared to historical data and I do not see any reason why we would have a sudden slow-down in build-out of EV infra.

To end above 53000 as on 29th April 2022 - Quarterly run rate has to be 8.9% or higher

Found this on their site plotting US charging installation over time. If you download the Excel sheet it notes that these numbers were from as late in each year as possible, so sometime in December. They include private charging stations but if I drop that out of the current numbers private stations are only a couple thousand. Level 1 stations also seem to be negligible, so if they're counting those it shouldn't matter either. Current number is about 45,000, which is an increase of about 13.2k over December of 2020, or about a 40% increase. That's pretty huge and well above trend, and we're also looking at a 6 month period. So for my low end estimate I'll assume an increase of a quarter of that in 6 months, which would get us to 48.3k stations. For the high end I'll assume the same increase of about 13.2k, so about 58.2k. The average of those two numbers is about 53.3k. But I'm going to skew it a bit toward the higher end because it does seem like electric vehicle adoption and infrastructure is accelerating. https://afdc.energy.gov/data/10964

The average EV station installation is about 7.5% per quarter (3,372; ignoring 2020Q2 due to COVID, steadily increasing as the economy opens). The high-end average for 2020 and 2021 is 7.8%. Using 8% as a high-end estimate for 1.5 quarters, there should be 5,396 new stations. This brings the station total to 48,568. However, the chip shortage is straining station production to a degree (https://electricautonomy.ca/2021/07/05/ev-charging-chip-shortage/). Although companies are increasingly committing to developing the EV infrastructure and the Biden Administration and congress are increasing incentives, I don’t see installations being above 9% for 1.5 quarters.   I found quarterly reports by googling "Electric Vehicle Charging Infrastructure Trends from the Alternative Fueling Station Locator: First Quarter 2020", then changing the year and quarter in the search.
Considering additional data, these modification better account for the actual make-ready numbers.

According to DOE's  Alternative Fuels Data Center, 44,966 charging stations are already in place.  However, IAW EV Adoption and other websites, there are already more than 63,000 Level 2 and DC Fast electric vehicle charging stations established.  Despite this confusion, it is clear that charging stations are going to increase in the very near future: In Feb 2021, the US officially reinstated its intent to meet Paris Agreement standards by 2025.  To meet the pollution reduction, the US will need to add more than 330,000 new public charging outlets by the end of 2025.  In addition, 100,000 Tesla rental cars will be on the road (through Hertz, in the US and Europe) in the next 14-months which will also increase the need for additional EV stations.

The best historical number I can find from the past pins EV stations at roughly 40,000 in Feb 2021.
https://www.statista.com/statistics/416750/number-of-electric-vehicle-charging-stations-outlets-united-states/ At the start of November 2021, there is an estimated 45,000. That's 5,000 in 9 months.  Roughly 555/month. Given straight line progression that would be 3,333 additional chargers. However GM announced installing at least 40,000 charging stations in calendar year 2022. 
https://www.detroitnews.com/story/business/autos/general-motors/2021/10/26/general-motors-partners-dealers-install-40-000-ev-level-2-chargers/6173005001/
The question resolves with 5 of those 12 months transpired, however the chargers won't start being shipped until the beginning of 2022 which isn't clear enough to determine how much progress can be achieved by the end of April. GM installed 100 out of 2750 in 12 months according to the article cited above so it reasonable to think there might be some meaningful limits on the amount of chargers that can be built, shipped, and installed in the next six months.  I will approximate no more than 4,000 will be able to be installed based on these limits. Hertz also announced it would be installing chargers in 65 cities concurrent with its recent 100,000 vehicle deal with Tesla. Unfortunately the details of number of chargers per city is difficult to determine therefore it is difficult to estimate the whole number of chargers to be installed. I will limit to a maximum of 1000 Therefore 45,000 + 3,333 + 4,000 + 1,000 = 53,333 as a maximum. I will start with largest percentage between 49,000 and 53,000 and monitor for updated progress on a monthly basis.

First update, based on a very simple, exploratory analysis of the 2021 new station data.  Tabulation of # new stations/month for Feb-Oct 2021 is given here: [602 553 833 803 668 744 794 1446 1853]. Why list just Feb-Oct? Well, January 2021 apparently had 11,171 new records in just that month (~1/4 of all stations ever)... so it seems that our data set of active charging stations may not have been "smoothly" entered in sync with the actual timing of new charging stations coming online. As others may have noticed too, there are a few specific dates ("Open Date" attribute in the table) that have a very disproportionately large number of records associated with them, e.g., 1/27/2021, 10/25/2021, etc. This suggests that the data entry methodology probably involves some "catch-up" periods where large pulses of backlogged records are suddenly added to the data set, far beyond the "normal" background accumulation rate of new station entries. This aspect of our data will presumably make prediction of the number of stations on 29 April 2022 a bit more "interesting", since at any point between now and April there could suddenly be, say, 10k new stations added from one month to the next. I recognize that I've casually assumed that such a high pulse of entries concentrated in a single day will reflect simple backlogs in data entry being addressed, but perhaps someone has an idea for how else these pulses might arise? (And how they might even be predictable?) For now, my forecast will assume that the recent months' station count data (as given above) will be typical going forward, so that the average monthly rate of new station adds over the question timeframe will be between 500/month and 1800/month, including maybe some additional "backlog-spikes". How to more optimally weight the various possible monthly growth rates that can be inferred from the data (noteworthy that September/October rates are much higher than the other months, but also include possible backlog-days!) will be very interesting to think about, as well as how to best account for the possibility of future "shocks" to the growth trends.  Will be interesting to see how this kind of "technical analysis" corresponds with predictions arising from "fundamentals", e.g., along the lines of points raised by @Scappleby

44,916 As of Oct 31, 2021.... so 6 months to go: "In California, which holds a third of America’s charging stations, one in five EV owners eventually switches back to a gas-powered vehicle citing dissatisfaction with charging convenience." 
https://thehill.com/opinion/technology/574926-how-the-us-can-build-ev-charging-infrastructure-that-works "The American Jobs Plan will establish grant and incentive programs for state and local governments and the private sector to build a national network of 500,000 EV chargers by 2030, while promoting strong labor, training, and installation standards." https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2021/05/18/fact-sheet-the-american-jobs-plan-supercharges-the-future-of-transportation-and-manufacturing/ Regardless of it's ambitions, the plan will be unlikely to significantly impact the results in the timeframe of the question. So... how fast are they being built...?
BTS shows 96,626 in 2020, so they're using different criteria than the question but could help with the trend (https://www.bts.gov/browse-statistical-products-and-data/state-transportation-statistics/alternative-fuel-stations). '17-'18 = 30% increase, '18-'19 = 30%, '19-'20 = 8% (which is easy to understand given that whole pandemic thing). So a 30% yoy increase may be the norm? or 15% in 6 months, which would put it at 51,653. It looks like sales have recovered to pre-pandemic levels and are growing but sill only account for 2% of all vehicles on the road. (https://www.bts.gov/data-spotlight/electric-vehicle-use-grows).  It also looks like California accounts for 1/3 of the current charger market with NY being second with barely 5%(https://afdc.energy.gov/stations/states). Cali also has ~40% of total sales (https://evadoption.com/ev-market-share/ev-market-share-state/). So, where's Cali in all this: "Southern California Edison announced a plan Monday, July 12, to exponentially multiply the number of passenger-car electric chargers it has placed in Southern California, by going from around 3,000 at present to more than 40,000 in the next four years." 
"SCE had about 5,500 charging ports at the end of 2020 in its service area when counting passenger car charging as well as heavy- and medium-duty charging stations for buses, trucks and fleet vehicles. SCE officials estimate it will add around 9,000 per year or more under the new program."
https://www.dailybulletin.com/2021/07/12/40000-charging-stations-for-electric-vehicles-planned-for-southern-california/ California is now listed as having 13,471, meaning they've built ~8k in 2021, which is well on track for their plan and puts them on pace for another ~4500 in the question. So they alone push the total to ~49.5k. If the rest of the country adds 30% to their total that would be another ~4500, putting the total at ~54k.  It seems that almost any scenario puts it past Bin 1. high Bin 2 seems most likely given current trends but there's a reasonable chance it could go past so I'll build out from there.

So if I adjust for this I get the current clip of installations to be ~70 stations installed per day. This bring us just north of 57k by the above date. Not sure if supply chain issues will slow it down, or initiatives to increase deployment increase it so will give somewhat similar estimates for >57k and <57k.

I’m not well-versed in past growth rates of charging station numbers, so casting a wide net for this first forecast. I’d be very surprised if the number grows by more than ~35% in six months, so not weighting the last few bins as much. Let’s see how we progress from the 44,876 stations reported on the day this question opened…

The experience charging with Tesla’s station is remarkably better than a public one. Tesla has hinted at offering their stations to other vendors. Doubtful(willing to be wrong!) that this will happen before the close date but if it does it could be a network effect in users seeking out Tesla stations. Tesla also has plenty of money and data about where users are buying their cars and where they are traveling to continue to land and expand in the most desirable areas for stations compared to other car manufacturers using a public network.
